body: Great, once it's published we will aad this option by default!

Hm, I don't think 4ac0e74 by itself does it, but I probably wasn't being clear. What I was looking for was the ability to watch the actual symlink (i.e. not follow it). This isn't the default behavior of chokidar;  you need to set the `followSymlinks` option (added in [284148b](https://github.com/paulmillr/chokidar/commit/284148bb3d118ee31241d167fa41036dcc088b59)) to `false` in order to get it. This issue was about providing a way in PM2 to set that option.
Ok, option is `true` by default but we could easily add an option to set it to `false`.

issue.title: File watching worked in 0.12.1 but does not in newer versions with Vagrant/Virtualbox/NFS shared folders configurations

repository.name: pm2
repository.description: Node.js Production Process Manager with a built-in Load Balancer.

issue.body:
Using Vagrant (1.7.2) with Virtualbox (4.3.20) on Mac OS X 10.10.1 and a Vagrant configuration which does the following:
- Uses Vagrant's build-in docker support to provision a virtual machine that mounts a NFS shared folder. This shared folder is exposed as a docker volume.
- Launches several docker containers, one of which runs PM2 to launch a Node.JS script. PM2 watches a sub-directory of the above docker volume.

In version 0.12.1 of PM2, I could edit a watched file on my Mac OS X host and PM2 would correctly restart the application. In (at least) 0.12.3 of PM2, this is no longer the case. If I SSH into the Virtualbox and touch the same file there, PM2 restarts the application.

I've debugged this for a couple of days and tried many different Vagrant/Virtualbox/Docker configurations thinking the issue lay there. But on a whim I tried installing an older version of PM2 that had been working in a similar project, and things started to work. I noticed that there were some file watching changes in 0.12.2. Perhaps some of these changes are causing this behaviour?

body:
@matthewwithanm Sorry for the big delay was really busy!

Hope that this PR'll fit your needs!

issue.title: Watching a symbolic directory

repository.name: pm2
repository.description: Node.js Production Process Manager with a built-in Load Balancer.

issue.body:
Hi

Our deployment process releases a new version of the code into a versioned folder e.g. wwwapi_v1.0.60. We then create / update a symbolic link wwwapi that points to the version folder.We start the application from symbolic link wwwapi using the following json file:
[{
  "name"             : "s008.wwwapi",
  "args"             : "['port=10800', 'host=0.0.0.0', 'platformKey=s008']",
  "script"           : "app.js",
  "cwd"              : "/var/www/s008/xxx.yyy.com/wwwapi",
  "log_date_format"  : "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm Z",
  "error_file"       : "/var/log/www/s008/xxx.yyy.com/wwwapi/stderr.log",
  "out_file"         : "/var/log/www/s008/xxx.yyy.com/wwwapi/stdout.log",
  "min_uptime"       : "1000s",
  "max_restarts"     : 15,
  "watch"            : true,
  "ignoreWatch"      : ["[\/\\]\./", "node_modules" ],
  "merge_logs"       : true,
  "exec_interpreter" : "node",
  "exec_mode"        : "fork",
  "env": {
    "NODE_ENV": "s008"
  }
}]

When we switch the symbolic link it fails to auto restart the application. This worked on version 12.4 (node v0.10.30 and Centos 6.5) but upgrading to version 12.14  (node v0.10.30 and Centos 6.5) has broken the auto restart process. 

Touching a file inside the symbolic directory caused the restart process if the symbolic link hasn't been updated. If the symbolic link updates, touching a file won't cause the restart.

Is there a new flag to make it work this way, or is this an issue that needs fixing?

Thanks

Craig
